content: Exploration of developmental mechanisms classically relies on analysis of pattern regularities. Whether disorders induced by biological noise may carry information on building principles of developmental systems is an important debated question. Here, we addressed theoretically this question using phyllotaxis, the geometric arrangement of plant aerial organs, as a model system. Phyllotaxis arises from reiterative organogenesis driven by lateral inhibitions at the shoot apex. Motivated by recurrent observations of disorders in phyllotaxis patterns, we revisited in depth the classical deterministic view of phyllotaxis. We developed a stochastic model of primordia initiation at the shoot apex, integrating locality and stochasticity in the patterning system. This stochastic model recapitulates phyllotactic patterns, both regular and irregular, and makes quantitative predictions on the nature of disorders arising from noise. We further show that disorders in phyllotaxis instruct us on the parameters governing phyllotaxis dynamics, thus that disorders can reveal biological watermarks of developmental systems. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.001

title: eLife digest
content: Plants grow throughout their lifetime, forming new flowers and leaves at the tips of their stems through a patterning process called phyllotaxis, which occurs in spirals for a vast number of plant species. The classical view suggests that the positioning of each new leaf or flower bud at the tip of a growing stem is based on a small set of principles. This includes the idea that buds produce inhibitory signals that prevent other buds from forming too close to each other. When computational models of phyllotaxis follow these ‘deterministic’ principles, they are able to recreate the spiral pattern the buds form on a growing stem. In real plants, however, the spiral pattern is not always perfect. The observed disturbances in the pattern are believed to reflect the presence of random fluctuations – regarded as noise – in phyllotaxis. Here, using numerical simulations, Refahi et al. noticed that the patterns of inhibitory signals in a shoot tip pre-determine the locations of several competing sites where buds could form in a robust manner. However, random fluctuations in the way cells perceive these inhibitory signals could greatly disturb the timing of organ formation and affect phyllotaxis patterns. Building on this, Refahi et al. created a new computational model of bud patterning that takes into account some randomness in how cells perceive the inhibitory signals released by existing buds. The model can accurately recreate the classical spiral patterns of buds and also produces occasional disrupted patterns that are similar to those seen in real plants. Unexpectedly, Refahi et al. show that these ‘errors’ reveal key information about how the signals that control phyllotaxis might work. These findings open up new avenues of research into the role of noise in phyllotaxis. The model can be used to predict how altering the activities of genes or varying plant growth conditions might disturb this patterning process. Furthermore, the work highlights how the structure of disturbances in a biological system can shed new light on how the system works. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.002

full_caption: (<bold>A</bold>) wild type inflorescence of <italic>Arabidopsis thaliana</italic> showing regular spiral phyllotaxis. (<bold>B</bold>) <italic>aph6</italic> mutant inflorescence showing an irregular phyllotaxis: both the azimuthal angles and the distances between consecutive organs are largely affected. (<bold>C1</bold>) Organ initiation in the wild type: the size of organs is well hierarchized, initiations spaced by regular time intervals. (<bold>C2</bold>) Organ initiation in the <italic>ahp6</italic> mutant: several organs may have similar sizes, suggesting that they were initiated simultaneously in the meristem (co-initiations). (<bold>D</bold>) A typical sequence of divergence angles in the WT: the angle is mainly close to (≈ 137◦) with possible exceptions (M-Shaped pattern). (<bold>E</bold>) In <italic>ahp6</italic>, a typical sequence embeds more perturbations involving typically permutations of 2 or 3 organs. (<bold>F–I</bold>) Frequency histogram of divergence angle: wild type (<bold>F</bold>); <italic>ahp6</italic> mutant (<bold>G</bold>); WS-4, long days (<bold>H</bold>); WS-4 short days - long days (<bold>I</bold>).

The difference <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf29"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mi>k</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>−</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> in inhibition levels is higher than in A. (<bold>C</bold>) Variation of the distance <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf30"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>−</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> between the global minimum of the inhibition landscape and the local minimum with closest inhibition level (i.e. the second local minimum), as a function of <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf31"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow/></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>Γ. (<bold>D</bold>) Inhibition profile just before an initiation at azimuth 80° and (<bold>E</bold>) just after. (<bold>F</bold>) Variation of inhibition profile in time. As the inhibition levels of local minima decrease, their angular position does not change significantly, even if new primordia are created (peak <italic>q<sub>n</sub></italic>), color code: dark red for low inhibition and dark blue for high inhibition values. (<bold>G</bold>) Sequence divergence angles between initiations simulated with the classical model (control parameter <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf32"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>). At some point in time (red arrow), the choice of the next initiation is forced to occur at the 2th local minimum instead of the global minimum. After the forcing, the divergence angle makes a typical M-shaped pattern and returns immediately to the <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf33"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>α</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> baseline. title: Properties of the inhibition profiles in the classical model and effect of a forced perturbation on divergence angles and plastochrons.
label: Figure 3.
content: (A) Inhibition variation (logarithmic scale) along the peripheral circle and its global and local minima for a control parameter Γ1 = 0.975. Ek−E1 is the difference in inhibition levels between the kth local minimum and the global minimum. The angular distances between the global minimum and the kth primordiu inhibition m are multiple of the canonical angle (α=137°). (B) Similar inhibition profile for a control parameter Γ2 = 0.675 < Γ1. The difference Ek−E1 in inhibition levels is higher than in A. (C) Variation of the distance E2−E1 between the global minimum of the inhibition landscape and the local minimum with closest inhibition level (i.e. the second local minimum), as a function of Γ. (D) Inhibition profile just before an initiation at azimuth 80° and (E) just after. (F) Variation of inhibition profile in time. As the inhibition levels of local minima decrease, their angular position does not change significantly, even if new primordia are created (peak qn), color code: dark red for low inhibition and dark blue for high inhibition values. (G) Sequence divergence angles between initiations simulated with the classical model (control parameter Γ1). At some point in time (red arrow), the choice of the next initiation is forced to occur at the 2th local minimum instead of the global minimum. After the forcing, the divergence angle makes a typical M-shaped pattern and returns immediately to the α baseline. (H) Corresponding plastochrons: the forcing (red arrow) induces a longer perturbation of the time laps between consecutive organs. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.005

full_caption: The number of inhibition mimima is stable (3) in time. When the absolute minimum reaches the initiation threshold (here <italic>E</italic> = 0), a primordium is created that instantaneously creates a strong inhibition locally, which suddenly increases the inhibition level at its location. Between initiations, local minima regularly decrease in intensity due to the fact that growth is moving existing primordia away from the center. This movement is accompanied by a slight drift in position common to all primordia (here to the right).
title: Temporal variation of the inhibitory profile around the central zone in the classical model for a large value of the parameter Γ.

full_caption: As the perturbation intensity <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf132"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>π</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> increases, the percentage of 2-permutations decreases in a non-linear way to the benefit of more complex 3-permutations. In red: values of 2- and 3-permutations observed in different mutants and ecotypes of Arabidopsis thaliana (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib6">Besnard et al., 2014</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib37">Landrein et al., 2015</xref> and this study) placed on the plot of values predicted by the stochastic model.

We then used the combinatorial model (Refahi et al., 2011) to detect permutations in the simulated sequences. The model has mainly three parameters, β, E∗ and Γ. For each parameter value of β, E∗ and Γ, we run sixty simulations. Each simulation generated a sequence of 25 divergence angles. title: Key parameters controlling phyllotaxis phenotypes in the stochastic model.
label: Figure 6.
content: Phyllotaxis sequences were simulated for a range of values of each parameter β, E∗, Γ. Each point in the graph corresponds to a particular triplet of parameter values and represents the average value over 60 simulated sequences for this triplet. (A) Global amount of perturbation π as a function of the new control parameter ΓP=ΓβE∗. (B) Divergence angle α as a function of the control parameter Γ of the classical model on the Fibonacci branch. (C) Divergence angle α as a function of the new control parameter ΓD=Γ1β1/6E∗1/2 on the Fibonacci branch (here, we assume s = 3, see Appendix 1—figure 6 for more details). (D) Plastochron T as a function of control parameter of the classical model Γ. (E) Plastochron T as a function of the new control parameter ΓD. (F) Parastichy modes (i,j) identified in simulated sequences as a function of ΓD. Modes (i,j) are represented by a point i+j. The main modes (1,2), (2,3) … correspond to well marked steps. (Figure 5—source data 1) DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.013
caption: Phyllotaxis sequences were simulated for a range of values of each parameter β, E∗, Γ. Each point in the graph corresponds to a particular triplet of parameter values and represents the average value over 60 simulated sequences for this triplet. (C) Divergence angle α as a function of the new control parameter ΓD=Γ1β1/6E∗1/2 on the Fibonacci branch (here, we assume s = 3, see Appendix 1—figure 6 for more details). (D) Plastochron T as a function of control parameter of the classical model Γ. (E) Plastochron T as a function of the new control parameter ΓD. (F) Parastichy modes (i,j) identified in simulated sequences as a function of ΓD. Modes (i,j) are represented by a point i+j. The main modes (1,2), (2,3) … correspond to well marked steps. (Figure 5—source data 1)

full_caption: The detection algorithm (see ref [7] for details) searches plausible angle values, i.e. values within the 99% percentile given the Gaussian like distributions fitted in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig1">Figure 1</xref>, such that the overall sequence is <italic>n</italic>-admissible, i.e. composed of permuted blocks of length at most <italic>n</italic>. (<bold>A</bold>) When only 2- and 3-permutations are allowed, some angles in the sequences cannot be explained by (i.e. are not plausible assuming) permutations (the blue line of successfully interpreted angles is interrupted). (<bold>B</bold>) Allowing higher order permutations allows to interpret all the observe angles as stemming from 2-, 3- 4- and 5-permutations (the blue line covers the whole signal). Organs indexes involved in permutations: [3, 2], [5, 8, 6, 4, 7], [13, 12], [16, 14, 17, 15], [19, 18], [22, 21], [24, 25, 23], [27, 26], [30, 29], [32, 31], [35, 34], [39, 40, 38], [43, 42], [46, 45], [48, 49, 47], [52, 50, 53, 51].
title: Detection of higher-order permutations in WS4.
label: Figure 7.
content: The detection algorithm (see ref [7] for details) searches plausible angle values, i.e. values within the 99% percentile given the Gaussian like distributions fitted in Figure 1, such that the overall sequence is n-admissible, i.e. composed of permuted blocks of length at most n. (A) When only 2- and 3-permutations are allowed, some angles in the sequences cannot be explained by (i.e. are not plausible assuming) permutations (the blue line of successfully interpreted angles is interrupted). (B) Allowing higher order permutations allows to interpret all the observe angles as stemming from 2-, 3- 4- and 5-permutations (the blue line covers the whole signal). full_caption: (<bold>A</bold>) Inhibitory fields (red), possibly resulting from a combination of molecular processes, are generated by primordia. On the peripheral region of the central zone (CZ, green), they exert an inhibition intensity <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf246"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mi>t</mml:mi><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> that depends on the azimuthal angle <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf247"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>α</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> (blue curve). At any time <italic>t,</italic> and at each intensity minimum of this curve, a primordium can be initiated during a time laps <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf248"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>δ</mml:mi><mml:mi>t</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> with a probability <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf249"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mi>k</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mi>δ</mml:mi><mml:mi>t</mml:mi><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> that depends on the level of the inhibition intensity at this position. (<bold>B</bold>) Relationship between the classical model parameters and its observable variables. A single parameter <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf250"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> controls both the divergence angle and the plastochron. (<bold>C</bold>) Relationship between the stochastic model parameters and its observable variables. The stochastic model of phyllotaxis is defined by 3 parameters <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf251"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>,<inline-formula><mml:math id="inf252"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf253"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mo>∗</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>. The observable variables <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf254"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>α</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf255"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>T</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf256"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>π</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>π</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>π</mml:mi><mml:mn>3</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>… are controlled by two distinct combinations of these parameters: <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf257"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mi>D</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mfrac><mml:msup><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mrow><mml:mo>/</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mi>s</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msup><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mi>β</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mrow><mml:mo>/</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mn>6</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msup><mml:msup><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mo>∗</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mrow><mml:mo>/</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msup></mml:mrow></mml:mfrac></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> controls the divergence angle and plastochron while <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf258"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mi>P</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>β</mml:mi><mml:msup><mml:mi>E</mml:mi><mml:mo>∗</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula> controls the global percentage of permutated organs <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf259"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>π</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>, which in turns controls the distribution of permutation complexities: <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf260"><mml:mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>π</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>π</mml:mi><mml:mn>3</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:mstyle></mml:math></inline-formula>….
title: Structure of the stochastic model.
label: Figure 8.
content: (A) Inhibitory fields (red), possibly resulting from a combination of molecular processes, are generated by primordia. On the peripheral region of the central zone (CZ, green), they exert an inhibition intensity E(t) that depends on the azimuthal angle α (blue curve). At any time t, and at each intensity minimum of this curve, a primordium can be initiated during a time laps δt with a probability pk(δt) that depends on the level of the inhibition intensity at this position. (B) Relationship between the classical model parameters and its observable variables. A single parameter Γ controls both the divergence angle and the plastochron. (C) Relationship between the stochastic model parameters and its observable variables. The stochastic model of phyllotaxis is defined by 3 parameters Γ,β, E∗. The observable variables α, T and π,π2,π3… are controlled by two distinct combinations of these parameters: ΓD=Γ1/sβ1/6E∗1/2 controls the divergence angle and plastochron while ΓP=ΓβE∗ controls the global percentage of permutated organs π, which in turns controls the distribution of permutation complexities: π2,π3…. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.016

At any time t, and at each intensity minimum of this curve, a primordium can be initiated during a time laps δt with a probability pk(δt) that depends on the level of the inhibition intensity at this position. (B) Relationship between the classical model parameters and its observable variables. A single parameter Γ controls both the divergence angle and the plastochron. (C) Relationship between the stochastic model parameters and its observable variables. The stochastic model of phyllotaxis is defined by 3 parameters Γ,β, E∗. full_caption: (<bold>a</bold>) The first 10 primordia are depicted, with the generative spiral as a dashed line. The angle between successive organs is always equal to <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf286"><mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula>. The nearest neighbours of primordium <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf287"><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula> are <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf288"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>i</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>3</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf289"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>i</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>5</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>, hence the mode of this pattern is <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf290"><mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mn id="XM41">3</mml:mn><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mn id="XM42">5</mml:mn><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>. (<bold>b</bold>) 100 primordia are depicted, along with the 8 (resp. 13) parastichies oriented anticlockwise (resp. clockwise) indicated in cyan (resp. red), hence the mode of this pattern si <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf291"><mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:mn id="XM43">8</mml:mn><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mn id="XM44">13</mml:mn><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>.
title: Spiral phyllotaxis with divergence angle ϕ=137.5⁢\degree and different distributions of radial positions.
label: Appendix 1—figure 1.
content: (a) The first 10 primordia are depicted, with the generative spiral as a dashed line. The angle between successive organs is always equal to ϕ. The nearest neighbours of primordium i are i+3 and i+5, hence the mode of this pattern is (3,5). (b) 100 primordia are depicted, along with the 8 (resp. 13) parastichies oriented anticlockwise (resp. clockwise) indicated in cyan (resp. red), hence the mode of this pattern si (8,13). DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.017

full_caption: We used a sample of the interval <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf409"><mml:mrow><mml:mn>0.04</mml:mn><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:msup><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mn>2.9</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula> with steps of <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf410"><mml:mn>0.01</mml:mn></mml:math></inline-formula> or less (refinements were performed in areas with higher numbers of branches). For each value of <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf411"><mml:msup><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:math></inline-formula>, we ran simulations of the classical model with (i) spiral initial conditions for divergence angles taking integer values in <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf412"><mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">[</mml:mo><mml:mrow id="XM139"><mml:mn>20</mml:mn><mml:mo>⁢</mml:mo><mml:merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mml:mtext>\degree</mml:mtext></mml:merror></mml:mrow><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mrow id="XM140"><mml:mn>180</mml:mn><mml:mo>⁢</mml:mo><mml:merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mml:mtext>\degree</mml:mtext></mml:merror></mml:mrow><mml:mo stretchy="false">]</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>, and plastochrons taking values in a sample of 128 points between <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf413"><mml:mn>0.05</mml:mn></mml:math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf414"><mml:mn>8.00</mml:mn></mml:math></inline-formula>, (ii) whorled initial conditions for the same samples of divergence angles and plastochrons and all jugacies <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf415"><mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mi>j</mml:mi><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mn>7</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>. For each simulation, we estimated the final divergence angle <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf416"><mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula> and phyllotactic mode, and reported these in the graph above (abscissa: <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf417"><mml:msup><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:math></inline-formula>, ordinate: <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf418"><mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula>, color code: mode).
title: Bifurcation diagram in the Snow and Snow model.
label: Appendix 1—figure 2.
content: We used a sample of the interval 0.04≤Γ′≤2.9 with steps of 0.01 or less (refinements were performed in areas with higher numbers of branches). For each value of Γ′, we ran simulations of the classical model with (i) spiral initial conditions for divergence angles taking integer values in [20⁢\degree,180⁢\degree], and plastochrons taking values in a sample of 128 points between 0.05 and 8.00, (ii) whorled initial conditions for the same samples of divergence angles and plastochrons and all jugacies 2≤j≤7. For each simulation, we estimated the final divergence angle ϕ and phyllotactic mode, and reported these in the graph above (abscissa: Γ′, ordinate: ϕ, color code: mode). DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.14093.018
caption: We used a sample of the interval 0.04≤Γ′≤2.9 with steps of 0.01 or less (refinements were performed in areas with higher numbers of branches). For each value of Γ′, we ran simulations of the classical model with (i) spiral initial conditions for divergence angles taking integer values in [20⁢\degree,180⁢\degree], and plastochrons taking values in a sample of 128 points between 0.05 and 8.00, (ii) whorled initial conditions for the same samples of divergence angles and plastochrons and all jugacies 2≤j≤7. For each simulation, we estimated the final divergence angle ϕ and phyllotactic mode, and reported these in the graph above (abscissa: Γ′, ordinate: ϕ, color code: mode).
full_title: Bifurcation diagram in the Snow and Snow model.

full_caption: (<bold>A</bold>) An exponential model was fitted to the simulated data of <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf604"><mml:mi>π</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf605"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>P</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> using the Gauss-Newton least squares method (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib5">Bates and Watts, 2007</xref>); for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf606"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>P</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> values [8.30, 11.49] that could yield the observed <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf607"><mml:mi>π</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula> value 14.2 was determined by the prediction band. (<bold>B</bold>) A Gompertz function was fitted to the simulated data of plastochron and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf608"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>D</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> using the Gauss-Newton least squares method (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib5">Bates and Watts, 2007</xref>); for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf609"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>D</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> values [0.427, 0.492] that could yield the observed range of plastochron values [0.023, 0.028] was determined by the prediction band. (<bold>C</bold>) A 4th degree polynomial was fitted to the simulated data of angle and <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf610"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>D</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> using the least squares method; for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf611"><mml:msub><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mml:mi><mml:mi>D</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:math></inline-formula> values [0.384, 0.472] that could yield the observed angle value of 136was determined by the prediction band. (<bold>D</bold>) Distributions of the estimated plastochrons in the groups of wild-type and mutated Arabidopsis plants in the experiments of <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib6">Besnard et al., 2014</xref>. The box depicts the inter-quartile range bisected by the median, and the whiskers reach out to the extreme values in the group; the colored point denotes the arithmetic mean, and the colored dashes indicate twice the standard error of the mean; <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf612"><mml:mi>n</mml:mi></mml:math></inline-formula> stands for the number of plants in the group.
title: Estimation of control parameters from observable phyllotaxis variables.
label: Appendix 1—figure 3.
content: (A) An exponential model was fitted to the simulated data of π and ΓP using the Gauss-Newton least squares method (Bates and Watts, 2007); for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible ΓP values [8.30, 11.49] that could yield the observed π value 14.2 was determined by the prediction band. (B) A Gompertz function was fitted to the simulated data of plastochron and ΓD using the Gauss-Newton least squares method (Bates and Watts, 2007); for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible ΓD values [0.427, 0.492] that could yield the observed range of plastochron values [0.023, 0.028] was determined by the prediction band. (C) A 4th degree polynomial was fitted to the simulated data of angle and ΓD using the least squares method; for the fitted model, an approximate 95% prediction band was then computed by assuming the random error terms additive and i.i.d. normally distributed. The range of possible ΓD values [0.384, 0.472] that could yield the observed angle value of 136was determined by the prediction band. (D) Distributions of the estimated plastochrons in the groups of wild-type and mutated Arabidopsis plants in the experiments of Besnard et al., 2014. The box depicts the inter-quartile range bisected by the median, and the whiskers reach out to the extreme values in the group; the colored point denotes the arithmetic mean, and the colored dashes indicate twice the standard error of the mean; n stands for the number of plants in the group. full_caption: (<bold>a</bold>) As reported in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2">Figure 2H</xref>, forcing a primordium near the first or second local minima does not affect the phyllotactic mode permanently, but simply forces a 2-permutation in the case of the second minimum. (<bold>b</bold>) When primordia are introduced near the highest or second highest local maxima, the system returns to its previous pattern. Near the third maximum or the third minimum, the system changes pattern, in the shown simulation it converges to a spiral oriented in the opposite direction to the previous spiral (i.e. <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf728"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>φ</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mo>-</mml:mo><mml:mn>137.5</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula> instead of <inline-formula><mml:math id="inf729"><mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>137.5</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math></inline-formula>); a 2-permutation can be seen in the new spiral for the third maximum. New primordia introduced far from any maximum or minimum (black headed arrows) tend to disrupt the phyllotactic mode more significantly, converging to whorled patterns (primordia forced near 0 or near 290), or patterns involving high numbers of successive permutations (primordium forced near 150).
title: Effect of forcing initiation in different regions of the inhibitory field profile.
label: Appendix 1—figure 7.
content: (a) As reported in Figure 2H, forcing a primordium near the first or second local minima does not affect the phyllotactic mode permanently, but simply forces a 2-permutation in the case of the second minimum. (b) When primordia are introduced near the highest or second highest local maxima, the system returns to its previous pattern. Near the third maximum or the third minimum, the system changes pattern, in the shown simulation it converges to a spiral oriented in the opposite direction to the previous spiral (i.e. φ=-137.5 instead of +137.5); a 2-permutation can be seen in the new spiral for the third maximum. New primordia introduced far from any maximum or minimum (black headed arrows) tend to disrupt the phyllotactic mode more significantly, converging to whorled patterns (primordia forced near 0 or near 290), or patterns involving high numbers of successive permutations (primordium forced near 150).
